title: Bond option
text:
In <a href="finance">finance</a>, a bond option is an <a href="option%20%28finance%29">option</a> to buy or sell a <a href="bond%20%28finance%29">bond</a> at a certain price on or before the option expiry date. These instruments are typically traded <a href="Over-the-counter%20%28finance%29">OTC</a>.
Generally, one buys a <a href="call%20option">call option</a> on the bond if one believes that <a href="interest%20rate">interest rate</a>s will fall, causing an increase in bond prices. Likewise, one buys the <a href="put%20option">put option</a> if one believes that interest rates will rise. One result of trading in a bond option, is that the price of the underlying bond is "locked in" for the term of the contract, thereby reducing the <a href="credit%20risk">credit risk</a> associated with fluctuations in the bond price.
Valuation.
<a href="bond%20%28finance%29">Bonds</a>, the <a href="underlying">underlyers</a> in this case, exhibit what is known as <a href="pull%20to%20par">pull-to-par</a>: as the bond reaches its maturity date, all of the prices involved with the bond become known, thereby decreasing its <a href="volatility%20%28finance%29">volatility</a>. On the other hand, the <a href="Black%E2%80%93Scholes">Black–Scholes</a> model, which assumes constant volatility, does not reflect this <a href="Stochastic%20process">process</a>, and cannot therefore be applied here; <a href="http%3A//kalotay.com/sites/default/files/private/BlackScholes.pdf"></a> see <a href="Black%E2%80%93Scholes%20model%23Valuing%20bond%20options">Black–Scholes model #Valuing bond options</a>.
Addressing this, bond options are usually valued using the <a href="Black%20model">Black model</a> or with a <a href="Lattice%20model%20%28finance%29">lattice-based</a> <a href="short-rate%20model">short-rate model</a> such as <a href="Black%E2%80%93Derman%E2%80%93Toy%20model">Black-Derman-Toy</a>, <a href="Ho%E2%80%93Lee%20model">Ho-Lee</a> or <a href="Hull%E2%80%93White%20model">Hull–White</a>. <a href="http%3A//pages.stern.nyu.edu/~eelton/debt_inst_class/option%2520valuation.pdf"></a> The latter approach is theoretically more correct, <a href="https%3A//books.google.com/books%3Fid%3DwF8yVzLI6EYC%26amp%3Bprintsec%3Dfrontcover%26amp%3Bdq%3DValuation%2Bof%2Bfixed%2Bincome%2Bsecurities%2Band%2Bderivatives"></a>, although in practice the Black Model is more widely used for reasons of simplicity and speed. For <a href="American%20option">American-</a> and <a href="Bermudan%20option">Bermudan-</a> <a href="option%20style">styled options</a>, where exercise is permitted prior to maturity, only the lattice-based approach is applicable.
Embedded options.
The term "bond option" is also used for option-like features of some bonds ("<a href="embedded%20option">embedded option</a>s"). These are an inherent part of the bond, rather than a separately traded product. These options are not mutually exclusive, so a bond may have several options embedded. <a href="http%3A//financial-dictionary.thefreedictionary.com/embedded%2Boption"></a> Bonds of this type include:
Callable and putable bonds can be valued using the lattice-based approach, as above, but additionally allowing that the effect of the embedded option is incorporated at each node in the tree, impacting the bond price and / or the option price as specified. <a href="https%3A//books.google.com/books%3Fid%3DwF8yVzLI6EYC%26amp%3Bprintsec%3Dfrontcover%26amp%3Bdq%3DValuation%2Bof%2Bfixed%2Bincome%2Bsecurities%2Band%2Bderivatives"></a> These bonds are also sometimes valued using <a href="Black%E2%80%93Scholes">Black–Scholes</a>. Here, the bond is <a href="Bond%20valuation">priced as a "straight bond"</a> (i.e. as if it had no embedded features) and the option is valued using the <a href="Black%E2%80%93Scholes%23Black.E2.80.93Scholes%20formula">Black Scholes formula</a>. The option value is then added to the straight bond price if the optionality rests with the buyer of the bond; it is subtracted if the seller of the bond (i.e. the issuer) may choose to exercise. <a href="http%3A//ocw.mit.edu/courses/sloan-school-of-management/15-414-financial-management-summer-2003/lecture-notes/lec20_options2.pdf"></a> <a href="https%3A//web.archive.org/web/20110304203828/http%3A//www.numa.com/derivs/ref/calculat/cb/calc-cbb.htm"></a> <a href="http%3A//www.stern.nyu.edu/~adamodar/pc/inv2ed/ill33p6.xls"></a> For convertible and exchangeable bonds, a more sophisticated approach is to model the instrument as a "coupled system" comprising an equity component and a debt component, each with different default risks; see <a href="Lattice%20model%20%28finance%29%23Hybrid%20securities">Lattice model (finance)#Hybrid securities</a>.
Relationship with caps and floors.
European Put options on zero coupon bonds can be seen to be equivalent to suitable caplets, i.e. <a href="interest%20rate%20cap">interest rate cap</a> components, whereas call options can be seen to be equivalent to suitable floorlets, i.e. components of <a href="interest%20rate%20floor">interest rate floor</a>s. See for example Brigo and Mercurio (2001), who also discuss bond options valuation with different models.
